results.title: Blokes and sheds - Dimitri
results.creator_credit: Sarah Wishart, Robi Watt, SBS Independent, South Australian Film Corporation, Australian Film Commission and Mark Thomson
results.brief_description:
One of 12 minidocos about blokes and their sheds in South Australia.
Dimitri lives in a suburban house in Adelaide. As we meet Dimitri we discover his intense love of Greek musical instruments. He is one of a few in Australia who makes bouzoukis, ouds and baglamas. We hear how Dimitri first got interested in his craft and how he made a special journey from Australia to Poland to learn from a master craftsman. Dimitri works in his brand new purpose built shed in the backyard, as he likes the flexibility of working all hours. We watch how Dimitri builds musical instruments and also welcomes and attracts his friends and colleagues to the shed to share in the unique sound of those instruments he loves and makes. Based on the book by Mark Thomson.

results.title: Blokes and sheds - Silvio
results.creator_credit: SBS Independent, South Australian Film Corporation, Australian Film Commission, Mark Thomson, Sarah Wishart and Robi Watt
results.brief_description:
One of 12 minidocos about blokes and their sheds in South Australia.
In the scenic Adelaide Hills, Silvio, a well-known sculptor, spends all of his time working in his shed. He tells us how he and his family came to grow up in Australia after his father was a Hungarian pilot for the Germans in the war. Silvio began carving when he was five years old, carving bark off pine trees, soap, and bits of wood. He now creates life-sized beautifully ornate carved animals…pelicans, lizards and frogs from wood, stone and bronze. We see Silvio working with true commitment and passion in his enormous shed, as he works on creating the animals that he loves. Based on the book by Mark Thomson.
results.creator_credit_for_label: SBS Independent, South Australian Film Corporation, Australian Film Commission, Mark Thomson, Sarah Wishart and Robi Watt

results.title: Blow
results.creator_credit: Ted Demme, Denis Leary, Joel Stillerman and New Line Cinema
results.brief_description: Produced and directed by the late Ted Demme, Blow hurtles through three heady decades in the life of notorious drug dealer George Jung (Johnny Depp). From Jung’s early days selling marijuana on California beaches, through to multi-million dollar cocaine deals with gun-toting Columbians, Demme takes full advantage of the changing music, clothes and hairstyles of the 60’s, 70’s and 80’s. The fast pace, black humour and violence of the drug world is tempered by the gentler story of Jung’s failed relationships with his father (Ray Liotta) and his daughter. Cast includes Penelope Cruz, Rachael Griffiths, Paul Reubens, Jordi Molla and Franka Potente.

results.title: Blokes and sheds
results.creator_credit: SBS Independent, South Australian Film Corporation, Australian Film Commission, Mark Thomson, Sarah Wishart and Robi Watt
results.brief_description:
The backyard shed is an Australian icon. It may appear, to the unenlightened, to be a tacked-together corrugated iron structure full of junk, nails and spiders. In truth, it has become a peculiarly Australian horde of stories and myths about isolation, masculinity, identity, capability, self esteem, tradition and even passionate obsession. It is history on a very human scale, a one-person size record of a life. There is a mystery to a shed, with dark corners; yet grace, too in odd and unexpected ways. By talking to the owners and occupiers of twelve vastly diverse sheds all over South Australia, ‘Blokes and Sheds’ casts a gentle enquiring light into those cobwebbed nooks and crannies to tease out many paradoxes and passions. Each shed is the setting for its owner to open their hearts and share their stories in these twelve, two-minute documentaries.
Based on the book by Mark Thomson.

results.title: Bloodlust
results.creator_credit: Jon Hewitt, Richard Wolstencroft and Windhover Productions
results.brief_description: The most controversial and acclaimed cult hit since “Mad Max.” Banned in seven countries including Britain, “Bloodlust” is the tale of three modern day vampires on a bullet-riddled rollercoaster to hell. Winner Finalist Award “Best Film” Worldfest Housten, Texas. Starring John Stuart Wallace, Kelly Chapman, Robert James O’Neill and Phil Motherwell. Music by Revolting Cocks, Pailhead, Lead into Gold and 100 Homo DJ’s.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jon Hewitt, Richard Wolstencroft and Windhover Productions

results.title: Bloodbath at the house of death
results.brief_description: Imagine all the horror films you have ever seen, blend them together in one big send-up and you have “Bloodbath and the house of death” written by Barry Cryer along with Ray Cameron who also produced, directed as well as acted in a bit part in the film. It’s all there from the howling wind, shutting doors, shadowy figures and things that go bump in the night to satanic rituals and mass murders and a good measure of blood and guts. It begins at a rural English estate at Headstone Manor where sometime before, a bloody massacre of eighteen people occurred, and ever since, the Manor has purported to be haunted by a satanic phenomena. Six scientists are sent to Headstone Manor to investigate and what follows is a parody of events building up to the planned killing of the scientists by the quite crazy “Sinister Man” (beautifully hammed up by Vincent Price), leader of the Satanic cult who inhabit the Manor. This is total spoof with lots of one-liners, soap-opera acting and a touch of Python humor - very British and quite entertaining. Stars well-known British TV comedian Kenny Everett as Dr Lukas Mandeville and Pamela Stephenson as Dr Barbara Coyle. Cast also includes Gareth Hunt, Don Warrington, John Fortune, Sheila Steafel, John Stephen Hill, Cleo Rocos and Graham Stark.

results.title: Blood: the last vampire
results.creator_credit: Hiroyuki Kitakubo, Ryuji Mitsumoto, Yukio Nagasaki and Production IG
results.brief_description: It is 1966, and the Vietnam War has just erupted. After a spate of suicides at the military school on the grounds of the U.S controlled Yokota Air Force Base in Japan are attributed to chiropterans, demons who live off human blood, a top secret organisation orders the mysterious and brooding Saya to hunt down and destroy the vile creatures responsible. Armed with a special samurai sword, Saya infiltrates the school in the guise of a new student, and launches a covert investigation, which soon leads her to the source of the problem. However, one of the chiropterans manages to escape, and Saya suddenly has her hands full when the school nurse is captured. It soon becomes a race against time to slay the demons before they take over the Base and kill all the humans within in it. Based on the manga of the same name, this fast-paced film is essentially a section of a much larger story, and is the first fully digital anime ever created. Instead of cels, the film used a computer system that created frames digitally from scanned artwork, using a computer to paint each frame. Director Hiroyuki Katakubo originally started off as an animator, before getting his first gig as a director on the hentai series, Cream Lemon. He has now established himself among the top anime directors, directing films such as ‘Roujin-Z’ (1991) and contributing to an episode of ‘Robot Carnival’ (1987). This video also features a documentary detailing the making of the ‘Blood: the last vampire’.

results.title: Blood sweat and tears. Vol. 4
results.creator_credit: Denny Lawrence, Frank Seres and Frank Seres Productions
results.brief_description: Narrated by Chris Haywood, this final volume of the series “Blood sweat and tears: Australians and sport” includes the episodes: “Bought sport” investigates the issues surrounding commercial sponsorship of sport, both amatuer and professional and asks the question - if sport was supposed to be the great equaliser, spreading ideals about manliness, team spirit and fair play, and with so much money riding on a win, have the ideals of sport been corrupted? “Political football” looks at the issues of how politics influence sport - athletes have long complained about victimisation by sporting bureaucrats. Sport and politics don’t mix and can sport, realistically, be amoral? “Wearing the green and gold” focuses on why Australian athletes feel they must achieve recognition in the world sporting arena in order to feel they have succeeded in their chosen field. Why isn’t reaching the pinnacle of your chosen sport in Australia enough?
results.creator_credit_for_label: Denny Lawrence, Frank Seres and Frank Seres Productions
results.description: Narrated by Chris Haywood, this final volume of the series “Blood sweat and tears: Australians and sport” includes the episodes: “Bought sport” investigates the issues surrounding commercial sponsorship of sport, both amatuer and professional and asks the question - if sport was supposed to be the great equaliser, spreading ideals about manliness, team spirit and fair play, and with so much money riding on a win, have the ideals of sport been corrupted? “Political football” looks at the issues of how politics influence sport - athletes have long complained about victimisation by sporting bureaucrats. Sport and politics don’t mix and can sport, realistically, be amoral? “Wearing the green and gold” focuses on why Australian athletes feel they must achieve recognition in the world sporting arena in order to feel they have succeeded in their chosen field. Why isn’t reaching the pinnacle of your chosen sport in Australia enough?
description_for_label: Narrated by Chris Haywood, this final volume of the series “Blood sweat and tears: Australians and sport” includes the episodes: “Bought sport” investigates the issues surrounding commercial sponsorship of sport, both amatuer and professional and asks the question - if sport was supposed to be the great equaliser, spreading ideals about manliness, team spirit and fair play, and with so much money riding on a win, have the ideals of sport been corrupted? “Political football” looks at the issues of how politics influence sport - athletes have long complained about victimisation by sporting bureaucrats. Sport and politics don’t mix and can sport, realistically, be amoral? “Wearing the green and gold” focuses on why Australian athletes feel they must achieve recognition in the world sporting arena in order to feel they have succeeded in their chosen field. Why isn’t reaching the pinnacle of your chosen sport in Australia enough?

results.title: Blood sweat and tears. Vol. 3
results.creator_credit: Frank Seres and Frank Seres Productions
results.brief_description: Narrated by Chris Haywood, the third volume of “Blood sweat and tears: Australians and sport” includes the following episodes: “Punters and wowsers” examines why we are so good at sport and why we are so passionate about it. Our sporting prominence owes a lot to gambling, and to those wowsers who tried to tame the wild punters and stamp out the gambling. The war still rages today! “Image makers” delves into the dazzling world of televising sport, which has become an incredibly complex art form, and begs the question: will sport become something we enjoy mainly from our armchair? “You’ve got to have heart” investigates the reasons why some people push themselves to the limits of their endurance as it almost seems as if they feel unfulfilled unless they make their dreams of achievement a reality.

results.title: Blood sweat and tears. Vol. 2
results.creator_credit: Frank Seres and Frank Seres Productions
results.brief_description: Narrated by Chris Haywood, this second volume of the four volume series “Blood sweat and tears: Australians and sport”, includes the episodes: “Silvertails & yobbos” which investigates the gulf that exists between the public access areas at sporting venues and the areas reserved for members only - is it really only money that separates the “classes” today? “Beauty and the beast” focuses on the struggle for women against rigid atittudes to be equal in the sporting arena - to have their achievements recognised on the same level as male sporting achievements. “Blood and guts” looks at how a mere game can turn murderous - the increase in violence in sports, such as Australian Rules football, and the extraordinary jump in the number of serious injuries in recent years.
